intro: Paepalanthus fuscoater, commonly known as the dark-leaved puya, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its rosette-forming leaves that are typically dark green to reddish in color. The plant produces striking inflorescences with showy, tubular flowers that attract pollinators such as hummingbirds and bees. It thrives in high-altitude environments with cool, humid climates and well-drained soil. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
